about.title: About the Commission
about.vision: Global leadership in combating corruption and organized crime.
about.mission: Human societies free of corruption and organized crime.
about.values: Transparency, humanity, universality, quality and professionalism.
goals: Contribute to international efforts to combat corruption and organized crime and develop effective preventive measures.
Advocate for the implementation of international mechanisms, plans and programs to fight corruption and organized crime, especially the United Nations Convention against Corruption.
Raise awareness of the risks and social impact of corruption.
Support civil society organizations to actively contribute to anti-corruption efforts.
Conduct legal studies to evaluate and review relevant local and international legislation, its effectiveness, and alignment with desired objectives.
Urge states lacking anti-corruption frameworks to adopt such laws and provide technical advice when needed.
Help follow up corruption cases and prepare files for study by competent national and international bodies.
Deliver capacity-building programs for specialized agencies and civil society organizations and interested individuals.
Promote integrity as an ethical value and explain the risks and impacts of corruption.
Provide technical assistance and advisory services to implement international decisions such as asset recovery in coordination with relevant entities.
Provide technical assistance on measures required for implementing international anti-corruption decisions in coordination with competent authorities.

who.title: Who We Are
body: The International Commission Against Corruption and Organised Crime is an independent, non-governmental, non-profit organization based in Geneva, focusing on issues that affect people’s lives, foremost corruption and organized crime.
We collaborate with entities and individuals who share our goals and are ready to contribute to combating these crimes.
Established in the heart of Europe, near the United Nations, to contribute to international peace and security, support law-enforcement agencies, and empower civil society.

activities.title: What We Do
items: Organizing and participating in seminars, conferences and workshops on combating corruption and organized crime at local, regional and international levels.
Forming national and international teams to amend and develop laws.
Concluding partnerships, understandings and agreements with relevant entities.
Cooperating with universities and civil society to deliver education, training and awareness programs.
Receiving reports, complaints and tips and referring them for verification and follow-up by competent bodies.
Cooperating with media outlets to run public awareness campaigns.
Using international occasions, such as International Anti-Corruption Day, to promote integrity.
Encouraging cooperation among stakeholders and strengthening social partnership.
Encouraging and participating in international anti-corruption awards.

mali.title: Mali: the crossroads between smuggling, terrorism and transnational crime
mali.body:
Mali :the crossroads between smuggling, terrorism and transnational crime.
Mali is suffering from a severe fuel crisis, compounded by other accumulated crises including security, political, and financial problems. International experts estimate that the current regime in the country could collapse within a short period. This hypothesis is reinforced by the loss of government control over several northern regions of the country and the ability of the armed Azawad movement to extend its control there.

haftar.title: Haftar: An Empire of Money, Power, and Corruption
haftar.body:
Haftar: An Empire of Money, Power, and Corruption
Since seizing control of eastern Libya, retired General Khalifa Haftar has amassed a huge fortune through various business activities and other operations to acquire money through legal and illegal means. He and his sons, especially his expected successor Saddam Haftar, have become the sole masters.

morocco.title: Morocco: Accumulated crises and corruption undermine reform efforts
morocco.body: Morocco: Accumulated crises and corruption undermine reform efforts. Moroccan Prime Minister and businessman Aziz Akhannouch came to power a few years ago with many promises of economic, financial and political reform, fighting corruption and achieving sustainable development, but little of that has been achieved.

europe.title: Will Europe Wean Itself Off Russian Gas?
europe.body:
Will Europe Wean Itself Off Russian Gas?
Since the start of the Russian war on Ukraine nearly three and a half years ago, Europe has been steadily and rapidly striving to reduce its dependence on Russian gas. However, this trend has encountered numerous obstacles, including the scarcity of viable alternatives and the indispensable reliance of some European countries, particularly those in Eastern Europe, on Russian gas. Can Europe tame its appetite for Russian Gas in light of international pressure from Washington.

smuggling.title: People smuggling, networks and political dimensions
smuggling.body:
People smuggling, networks and political dimensions
The story of human smuggling across borders into Europe and America intertwines organized crime, terrorism, drug and arms trafficking, and political corruption, making the unraveling of this dilemma one of the biggest challenges facing political, security, and economic decision-makers in both the West and the East.

sudan.title: Support Militia in Sudan, Lines of support
sudan.body:
Support Militia in Sudan, Lines of support
Many crimes have been committed by the Rapid Support Forces in Sudan since their confrontation with the Sudanese army began several years ago, but the crimes committed by the militia members and published on social media revealed unprecedented brutality and the involvement of regional and international support networks in what happened.
